title: Despite my long experience and best efforts, ‘Delhi belly’ got me
text:
I’ve got the trots. It’s the full catastrophe, both ends, sudden eruptions in the middle of the night. It’s unusual, I’m a road-tested traveller, I tend to stay in decent hotels and I’m careful with what I put in my mouth. Stomach problems rarely come my way but there’s no such thing as total immunity. I’m not the only one though, at least half the group I’m travelling with are experiencing the same symptoms.

Even if you’re careful with what you eat in a foreign country, you could still fall victim to a viral stomach bug. Credit: iStock

Bali belly, the Turkish trots, the Rangoon runs, there are some countries in the world where the state of your bowels becomes the standard topic of conversation. According to the Travelers Diarrhea study published on the US National Library of Medicine website, diarrhoea is the most common travel-related condition, estimated to affect 40 to 60 per cent of travellers. The most common cause is the E. coli bacteria, thought to be responsible for about 30 per cent of cases, although salmonella, listeria and viruses such as the highly contagious norovirus, the scourge of cruise ships, are among other reasons for busy bowel syndrome.

In the case of a bacterial infection, the most likely causes are contaminated water, unpasteurised dairy products, undercooked meat or fish, food stored at unsafe temperatures or in an unhygienic environment.

I’m betting mine is viral rather than bacterial. The first to come down in my group fell sick just a few days into the trip. But only half the group is stricken with the same symptoms. We’ve all been eating the same things and there’s another group with the same problems who have just arrived at our hotel, coming from a different direction, and that suggests a virus.

title: Driver fears $410 road fine is impacting job prospects: 'It's unfair'
text:
Montana Shaw believes the driving offence she carries from a passenger's wrongdoing is affecting her chances of getting a job.

Montana Shaw's mum was taking her jacket off when they drove past the roadside camera in Sydney. Source: Supplied

A recent graduate fears her years of hard work could be jeopardised by a split-second decision made by a passenger in her car. Montana Shaw, 22, was heading to an event at Sydney's International Convention & Exhibition Centre in September when her mum removed her heavy puffer jacket while seated in the vehicle.

Just as they passed a roadside camera, her mum's seatbelt "slipped under her boob" as she twisted to take the garment off. As a result, the young driver copped a $410 penalty and three demerit points for her passenger's seatbelt not being worn correctly — an offence she worries will now impede her career.

"It was such bad timing," Montana told Yahoo News Australia. "I have to detail this driving fine in job applications now... I've just completed a bachelor of law... and I'm looking to get into a government job."

Due to the nature of her work, the applications are extensive and often ask candidates to provide details on any previous criminal activity. This is where the issue with the driving fine comes in.

ADVERTISEMENT

"When I go to a job application it'll ask standard questions like, 'Have you been in jail?', 'Have you received a fine?'... now every time I have to tick the box and let them know, yes, I have had a fine," she said.

Driver concerned fine will impede on her job prospects

Montana's mum paid the fine and looked into changing the offence over to her name, but the pair ultimately came to the realisation the driver would have to take on the responsibility and cop the three demerit points as specified by driving laws.

"There was one application where it asked how many points I've accrued... it's a little frustrating because it wasn't my fault and I've not had any before. I can understand if it's a speeding fine," she told Yahoo. "The fact that I had to outline the fine I got that wasn't my fault is unfair."

Montana now has to include details of the driving offence in her job applications. Source: Supplied

Have you copped a driving offence due to a passenger's wrongdoing? Get in touch with sophie.coghill@yahooinc.com

ADVERTISEMENT

She believes the fine could very likely hinder her chances of being contacted for interviews, fearing many recruitment softwares simply clear out applications that tick a 'yes' for answers to do with criminal activity and fines without looking at the circumstances.

"I am worried that I won't get through all the stages now that that box is ticked... I have to wear it for five years," she said.

Do you have a story tip? Email: newsroomau@yahoonews.com.

You can also follow us on Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, Twitter and YouTube.

title: Young Aussie's $380 find among rubbish put out for council collection in 'wealthy' suburb
text:
Council rubbish enthusiast Em says there is 'more than enough for everyone' to start searching for their own hidden gems.

Amateur treasure hunter Em says there are plenty of valuable items to be found in Australia's richest suburbs. Source: TikTok/Sydstreetbounty

A young Aussie has proven someone's trash truly is someone else's treasure, after making an incredible $380 discovery in a pile of rubbish put out for council collection in one of the country's most affluent suburbs.

Sydneysider Em, who describes herself as an "amateur treasure hunter" had no idea how valuable the innocent-looking pen she picked up in the eastern suburb of Vaucluse would end up being.

"Nothing really drew me to it besides the fact that it was a bit heavier than a regular pen and had a base to store it in, and a bit of etching of a logo in the bottom of it," she told Yahoo News Australia.

But when she got it home and did some research, she learned the item she innocently picked up to decorate her desk is a designer item made by ACME Studios which retails for $380 new. The pen, which is made out of lathe spun rosewood and is gold plated, is the work of Italian designer Matteo Thun.

ADVERTISEMENT

"It really was just a bit of luck," she said.

Em has furnished her entire house with items she's found on the kerb waiting for council collection. Source: TikTok/Sydstreetbounty

The treasure hunting trend across Aussie suburbs

Em explained that after she began using a Lime Bike as her main form of transport, she "started realising how much valuable waste is put out on Sydney's streets every day.

"At least in the inner city and inner west, there really is a culture of putting perfectly usable items out on the sidewalk with the expectation that people will rummage through it and take whatever they need," she said.

Unfortunately, what isn't picked up will end up in landfill, she said. According to the NSW Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Sydney's landfills are set to run out of space by 2030 — putting a ticking clock on the need to increase recycling rates and divert food waste.

Em started out "paying more attention" to online groups to find freebies, but it wasn't long before she realised people were sharing maps and dates of council collections around the city. Since the beginning of the year, Em has headed out five times to areas like Woollahra, Bellevue Hill, Watsons Bay and Vaucluse, all of which are in the top 10 wealthiest suburbs in all of Australia.

ADVERTISEMENT

"It’s well worth the time to go and see what these people are throwing away," she told Yahoo. So far, she's found pianos, barbecues, televisions, sturdy tables, working Dyson vacuum cleaners, lamps, and plants.

"I’ve pretty much furnished my entire house doing this over the summer and it’s been fantastic for my wallet," she said.

Treasure hunter's tips to Aussies who want to get involved

While Em admits "some junk is just junk" much of the stuff people throw out can be made new again with a clean or repair. "A lot of people really don’t know the value of what they’re throwing away, but for the people willing to make the effort and glove up, it’s anyone’s game," she said.

Her advice to anyone looking to get their hands dirty and sift through rubbish left on the kerb for council collection is that it's important to wear gloves and sunscreen first and foremost.

"Look in drawers (because sometimes people forget to empty them), respect the people of the suburb and don’t make a mess of the street while looking through," she said. "Don’t worry about what time you go, there really is more than enough for everyone."
